title: Zuckerberg defends messaging app encryption in wake of government criticism
text:
The Facebook co-founder and CEO resisted pressure from three of the Five Eyes—the U.S., the U.K. and Australia—who argued in a disapproving letter that end-to-end encryption allows cybercriminals to dodge investigators. Mark Zuckerberg admitted that encrypting messages impedes the investigation of crimes like child exploitation and terrorism, but said the company would use other methods to combat such crimes. (Reuters)

Talking point: The open letter stands in stark contrast to another written by about 50 civil organizations—including the Canadian Internet Registration Authority, the American Civil Liberties Union, and Digital Rights Watch—which called on Facebook to “stay strong” on encryption. While the governments argued it reduces public safety, the civil rights groups said it is crucial for maintaining public safety and democratic values. One sticking point is the creation of “backdoors” that would allow authorities to decrypt messages—privacy advocates argue their creation defeats the purpose of encryption. Canada is notably not among the critical letter’s signatories, with encryption proving a sticky subject for Ottawa. Earlier this year, the government joined a public Five Eyes statement warning that it increases the proliferation of online child exploitation, but has also told The Globe and Mail it is not seeking legislation that would weaken encryption.
